job_title: Better Not to Disclose in Washington, DC
pros: IMC has a noble mission and incredible reach worldwide, with some great people on the ground devoted to the work and wanting to do great things. The organization can attract great people but retention is a different story.
cons: There are serious issues with management and culture, including bullying at multiple levels, nepotism, use of fear tactics and unrealistic or unclear goals and expectations. Some managerial behavior is really unacceptable and abusive. There is little career development and promotion is not based on clear or fair metrics. There is also a lack of overall organizational strategy guiding the work of individual departments and the CEO makes only rare appearances or efforts to connect to staff.

job_title: Senior Monitoring Evaluation Accountability & Learning Officer in Addis Ababa
pros: Because IMC is working as humanitarian work
cons: Capacity development is not majorly focused

pros: -Still some very good field operators out there working hard to make a difference
cons:
-Senior Managers at HQ overseeing field programs and operations are extremely paranoid, under qualified and overpaid, They take a 'dumb down' approach to management to protect their own jobs-- meaning that they hire under qualified staff to make sure they do not lose theirs.  Unfortunately this takes its toll on some very good field staff who have to pick up HQ slack and basically do everything for them.  Very top down approach.   
-Horrible working environment at HQ offices--no team feel, no team building exercises, no management meetings, no briefings on global programs, no momentum, no leadership.

-If you wish to progress and move up in the Organization based on merit, you better look elsewhere.

-There are no salary scales at IMC and they like it that way.  There is a huge variation in salaries across the board. Be prepared to be undercut and undervalued throughout your tenure there.If you stay too long you will use your sense of self-worth--don't do it!
-HR policies are dubious at best-- they exist only to protect the Organization's interests and those who form part of the inner circle and not the employee. 

-HR inner policies point towards hiring of third country nationals for field assignments over US Citizens regardless of if they are qualified to perform the job or not because it reduces the legal liability on the Organization.  Very sad to see how an Organization funded mostly by USG/ US tax payer dollars does not give Americans an equal shot at jobs.

pros: - Good Coordination, programming, advanced technical expertise

pros:

multi-diverse environment

toxic environment

very annoying supervisors

pros: Not to sound like a broken record, but many of the people who work for this organization are some of the most dedicated to the humanitarian sector and the beneficiaries of the organization.
cons: The mission of this organization is lost on many, though not all, of higher level management and feels like an afterthought when it comes to decision-making. There is very little consistent and organization-wide communication so staff are left to speculate everything from the health of the organization and decisions affecting majority of staff to when paid holidays are. The atmosphere has also become very negative from the increasingly high turnover and towering workloads where pretty much everyone is covering multiple jobs and struggling to stay afloat.  People who leave are very rarely replaced, even if they are critical to the organization.

pros: There were really no pros to working here. At least I have another notch on my resume. This doesn't mean much though. You mention International Medical Corps, and really it's just crickets.
cons: Interning at International Medical Corps was generally horrible.  There is no internship program. They have senior staff that are obviously very well-informed and seem like they would be lovely to talk to, but they don't set up any inhouse events for their interns. At the last ngo where I interned the executive director came in and spoke the interns for almost two hours. Wasn't given any substantial or challenging work. I realize it's an internship,  but you should at least give me something that makes me want to come in the office. Especially,  since I'm not being paid. Initially going into this internship I thought International Medical Corps could be a potential employer after I finish the last year of my master's probably. Having completed this internship,  I realize that International Medical Corps is not a place where I would like to work. Also,  there is a lot of gossip in this office. It is extremely unprofessional. Employees talk disparagingly of some employees when they're absent. Completely unacceptable.

pros: The organization is able to attract some good people.  That said, the truly great ones don't stay.  The work is meaningful in that it helps some of the world's most vulnerable people, but there is no focus on innovation, risk taking or non-linear leaps.  IMC does the same things now that it did 20 years ago.
cons: IMC is, hands down, the worst work environment I've ever been in.  Senior management is apathetic at best, and incompetent at worst.  No attention is paid to staff development, and resources are actually used to undermine and alienate staff. (E.g. studies on staff engagement that are suppressed and ignored.) There is no opportunity for career advancement, and no mentoring of junior staff. If you want a textbook case study in how not to run an organization from an HR, interpersonal and an innovation perspective, visit IMC.

review_title: Send few of senior managers to pension, its about the time
pros: I give the highest marks to the enthusiasm and the courage of employees in the field, who are giving their best to see the improvement of living conditions in their countries. I thank to desk officers with whom I worked with, for all understanding and support provided. I give the high score to the Innovation department. And that's about it.
cons: I am horrified by the spying atmosphere imposed by regional and HQ level, lack of transparency and bypassing procedures when ever HQ needs, and complete absence of awareness that people on the ground are not their toys and they are not working in mid-19th century gold-mining company but they are great humanitarian workers hoping to contribute as much as they can, to learn and to fulfil their potentials. HR don't serve employees at all. Most of the employees suffers from a burnout. The sense of abuse remains present for long time, after leaving IMC, and regret that the great effort is neither seen nor appreciated.

pros:
- Nice colleagues with interesting professional experience
- Good pay (expatriates)
- Interesting work overall

I think there is a huge potential for doing interesting work here, and the staff, especially national staff are extremely welcoming and willing to make a difference.
cons:
- No training, not much room for growth
- Weak management with the tendency to micro-manage
- Awkward flow of responsibility and communication between HQ and field

Communication is a major problem, and information sharing is haphazard. Furthermore, there is an overall lack of training, especially in the field, and it can be difficult to professionally grow in these expat positions. There's also a lack of clarity regarding roles and responsibilities in the mission where I work, which is extremely frustrating when starting off (linking this back to poor communicaiton and weak management). Also among management, there's a lot of petty politics and egos that inhibit a smooth implementation of activities.

pros: People doing the day-to-day work of the organization are generally bright, caring, hardworking, and extraordinarily competent at their jobs. Even the senior management cares about the level and quality of work performed. Work in the field (although hard to tell working in HQ offices) is usually high quality with great staff.
cons: There's high turnover for a reason. The CEO has founder's syndrome - micromanages and is constantly seeking for errors or mistakes. CEO also lacks vision and strategy, and professional demeanor. CEO has created a "culture of blame" at the organization, so everyone (at every level, senior management on down) is in defensive CYA mode. Senior management are generally high-quality, respectable people. Very little attention is given to professional development and attitude of caring - HR is more concerned with filling forms and abiding by rules than supporting staff. Organization could start its own chapter of Workaholics Anonymous - personal/work life balance is not respected and is even discouraged.

pros:
Salary scale is not superior but more than satisfactory.
A working environment where you can work very hard or where you can earn Money without doing anything. It is up to you.
cons:
Whether you work or don't work, you are appreciated same.
Tolerates some senior managers about many kinds of harrassment : mental and even sexual.
Codes of Conduct are part of the showroom, many times ignored.
Security in dangerous countries is highly neglected. 
Supports illegal outlaws of the host countries.
Even if you share above mentioned embarassing issues with Headquarters, nothing happens, you are punished, the actors of above issues are encouraged and you will become the only person loosing due to the others' non ethical actions.
ALL ABOVE MENTIONED ISSUES ARE BASED ON EVIDENCES. I AM READY TO DEFENCE MYSELF AGAINST ANY EVENTUAL LEGAL ATTACK.

pros:
1) The people in the field, they get what is needed and drive hard to deliver work in hard to reach and difficult environments to achieve success in our programs.  

2) The mission, the mission is strong to all and folks from the administrative to leadership get why International Medical Corps was founded and where we are today.

3) Excellent benefits, pension and retirement scheme is very competitive.
cons:
1) Work ethic, "make it happen now" or "needed this completed yesterday".  It's hard to comment a con on this when the organization is humanitarian and emergency response based but it's set us up to chase ourselves, continually.

2) No reasonable insurance to HQ spouses, there are no affordable options to HQ staff to provide insurance to their spouses.

review_title: Field teams great. Senior managers need to go.
pros: The field work that IMC conducts is incredibly important, and in my limited experience the local staff are incredibly engaging, conscientious and passionate about what they do.
cons: I whole heartedly agree with some of the earlier comments posted on this website. IMC senior management both in-country and at Regional Office are so overpaid and are totally incompetent. It is beyond me how some of these individuals were ever offered such important roles. These decisions reflect badly and I would argue will do nothing but harm IMC's reputation in the longer-term. Frankly, IMC needs to get rid of dead wood and bring in some decent professionals. I was very sad to leave but impossible to work with such incompetent senior staff.

pros:
I have been working for IMC for 10 years. Great people at all levels of the company - everyone is supportive of each other and has a great time together in accomplishing the mission.
The  Management team is  highly Motivated which brings much positive energy in the whole team. This is the definition of what a team should be.
I have never come across such company who has all the great qualities of Culture, Management, Career Advancement and Selfless people under a same roof.
cons: If you are looking to find negative in everything than you should work for yourself . Times are tough and it's easy to judge. Everyone can make a difference so if you want change, than you should change first

review_title: CEO and SMT running organisation dangerously close to complete phase out
pros: There are v strong committed staff in the field with some great first responder humanitarian programming  means they are still well respected in the countries.
cons: CEO systemically ignore calls for obvious reform and keeps slashing her most valuable asset: programmes. In response she Keeps her friends and boyfriend well paid with her LA inner circle club . Completely out of touch with how to run a philanthropic organisation - needs to go and allow fresh blood to rebuild the organisation from top down.

review_title: Major leadership vacuum, CEO is dis-connected from the realities of who we are and what we do and VPs are dis-engaged.
pros: Really committed staff on the shop floor at HQ and in the field. Strong middle managers but everyone suffers at the hands of weak senior leadership.
cons: Waste of resources with a top heavy management structure and a growing HQ despite major gaps in field management positions. Senior leadership never travel to field to see what is going on and don't seem to care about the real program work. Only interested in fund raising.

pros: The work itself can be meaningful, even inspiring, and the field offices can actually be decent places to work.  IMC is able to recruit (but not retain) fabulous talent, so you'll likely get the chance to work with some great folks.
cons: The culture at IMC is fundamentally broken.  Senior management is unfamiliar with basic best practices in engaging, motivating and retaining employees.  There are no opportunities for advancement and there is no investment in staff development.  The pay is well below market, and it is not unheard of for management to require employees to cover the cost of things like anti-malarials they require for trips to areas with malaria epidenimcs. If you are talented, innovative, bright and looking to work somewhere where you can receive support and career development, definitely seek employment elsewhere.  IMC is the worst work environment I've ever encountered.

pros: You really feel that your are helping vulnarable communities in different aspects in all Iraqi governorates. These fields are covering; NFI supplies, hygein kits, Women Empowerment Programs, Integration Programs & most of all a variety of Health Programs.
cons: Sometime you are requested to work more than the 45 hours a week. Sometimes during weekends & holidays. But as a matter of fact, I see this is an essential thing in the humanetarian work especially when there is a crisis.

pros: A community of motivated co-workers, training opportunities, challenge and responsibility. Culturally diverse, excellent team work and devotion to promoting health and saving lives as well as careers for young professionals.
cons:
I can't say anything about IMC global but IMC Ukraine is a mess. Absence of strategic planning, poor communication, poor networking, zero proactive attitude, no transparency, poor work ethics, job insecurity. 
IMC don't value their staff. There is a high dependency of donors and a tendency to shift interventions to match donor priorities. There is a lack of financial, project and organizational sustainability.

pros: A below-market paycheck? Some great co-workers who are stressed and in the process of burning out and leaving?
cons: The phrase "learned helplessness" applies to working at IMC.  The culture destroys its employees and drives them out, but until they go, they become resigned to intolerable, arbitrary, and unethical leadership, and begin to accept it as inevitable.  In talking with other former employees, I've discovered that many went through a "recovery" period, learning that in functional, well-run work places, things that are business-as-usual at IMC are simply not tolerated, and are in fact used as examples of what not to do.  IMC is an abusive, poorly run operation that demoralizes the good people it attracts.  Do yourself (and your friends and family) a favor, and don't work here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: At first I was very excited. What a great cause! Plus there are very interesting people that you get to work with. Good healthcare - which you need, because the job will take years off your life.
cons: Their internal systems are dated and inefficient. This more than tripled the time it took to do simple tasks. IT was always fixing issues with my computer, over and over and over. My manager was inexperienced and barely understood excel. In their defense, we shouldn't have had EVERYTHING in excel - it's 2015,not 1997. I could have worked every weekend and it wouldn't have been acknowledged as anything extraordinary.  I also had to work along side a toxic bully, who's behaviors was nurtured by an equally unpleasant VP. But that department hires people too young and inexperienced to know they could sue for the bullying they receive.

review_title: CEO & her Managers  arein  the wrong job
pros:
Some really great field staff who uphold humanitarian principles
Some operations & technical staff at hQ who are true professionals & committed to serving the populations in need
cons:
Major hemmorrhaging of public funds through highly paid CEO & her inner circle in LA office
Major mis management & zero support to frontline workers 
Total lack of accountability by board & CEO who only seem to care about their own agenda

review_title: Welcome, ambitious self-starters who don't need assurances from the top brass.
pros: If you are a self-starter and ambitious, you can climb the ladder fast - provided you make the right internal contacts.
cons: The presence of senior executive leadership in employees working life is non-existent.  The top execs don't communicate at all with the lower ranks - neither written or verbal communication.  Makes it seem like the organization top brass are out of touch or worse, don't care.

pros: Great work environment, dedicated staff and noble mission.  Benefits are reasonable.
cons: No paid maternity leave. High turnover. Poor internal communication and lack of transparency. Work/life balance varies based on department. It's a known risk you take when working for any emergency relief organization.

pros: While the quality of the programs varies, there is some great work going on at the field level in many countries.
cons: Almost no one stays more than 18 months, and most start looking for a new job within less than a year.  However, most of the people who occupy senior posts have been there for years, are generally not qualified to hold their jobs, and owe their positions to their personal friendships with the CEO. The problems with the organization today are the same problems that existed a decade ago - same management, same inability to learn and change.  This is a truly awful place to work.

pros: I had several opportunities to work with people across the organization and some unique learning opportunities. However, I did not feel I was consistently learning or growing in my position; it was more so that I had some isolated opportunities. There are a lot of people with interesting backgrounds so working here also helps you expand your professional and personal networks.
cons: It is difficult to find ways to grow and develop professionally, if you are in a position that is fairly consistent in responsibilities and tasks. There's a lot of turnover at HQ; it's discouraging to see and does make one question how much effort is put into retaining staff. One-on-one interactions with various staff are usually completely fine; however, the general office morale is low. The low morale makes it difficult to stay motivated or engaged, as many people (myself included) have a hard time seeing a future for themselves at the organization. I've heard of several staff who had negative experiences with HR. It seems there is a lack of transparency about HR policies and also general lack of transparency between those leading the organization and everyone else. Some departments are also fairly siloed; it would be beneficial to have more consistent interactions between departments to ensure that teams are working collectively and there are not duplicative efforts. Many of the organization's senior staff have been around for a long time - the lack of diversity in experience contributes to limited perspectives on how to get things done. The biggest challenge I encountered was that the organization has grown substantially in a short time but the processes and ways of doing business haven't changed to keep up with the growth. There's a very clear power struggle at the top of the organization - and at times it seems that this power struggle takes priority over making a true programmatic impact. Therefore, there are times when it feels like bureaucracy is inhibiting your ability to just do your work. Other reviews are completely accurate in that the focus is just on bringing money in.

pros: I have been working for International Medical Corps for almost 7 years. I can not express  enough what a wonderful workplace it is to work for. First of all I believe in the work that we do and what a great effect it has on the underserved communities we support. It makes me feel a sense of purpose and belonging.  I have had many amazing experiences and above all the opportunity to grow and learn. I would recommend to anyone to check out our website and see for themselves the difference we make in people's lives .
cons: none that i can think of

review_title: Poor senior leadership, strong emergency response work
pros: There are strong middle-level managers, with significant years of relevant work experience and management capacity. The work in the field to respond to humanitarian crises is well-known and generally well done. IMC staff around the world in the areas of health, mental health, gender-based violence, water hygiene and sanitation and nutrition are excellent! There are strong technical and program staff. If you are looking for a field position, you can get good field experience here.
cons:
The interal workings of IMC are poor compared to other international NGOs I've worked with. The general M.O. is to pursue the money, and quality of programs or internal processes is not important (so long as money is still flowing in).  You can see this reflected in their hiring and structures, (lack of) investments in real capacity building, and ignorance of real change for the people we say we helped after the acute emergency is over. 
The senior, senior leaders of the organization are a mixed bag of people that either aren't concerned about quality or have NO clue (for example, what is going in the field, what is good project management, what is sound practice for business development). The CEO is clueless - no interaction with staff and no field visits. A few folks in place at the top run the show without understanding processes that would be normal in other INGOs, making poor decisions that disrespect, de-motivate, and demoralize the middle-level staff who really know their stuff.  I would agree with other commenters that most HQ staff are fed-up.  There is nepotism and a general feeling amongst staff that the org does not care about them.  I know numerous talented, hard-working, dedicated staff that have had run-ins with human resources that show they could care less about you. Dedicated, talented staff are dispensable - they'll just get someone else. Forget about having a career path here unless you don't know a thing/have no relevant experience, because then you will get a promotion (no really, this is happening even now I hear). I think they keep relying on their image in the field to keep afloat (keep HQ staff coming in) but sooner or later (perhaps through these glassdoor reviews) people may realize that this org is not worth it. HR does not want to hear what staff have to say or fix really broken issues.  There is no transparency in decision-making and HR decisions, and rules change depending on who you know. No transparency in hiring process with regard to salary ranges - they do not share salary ranges. Benefits, especially travel recovery leave and vacation, are deplorable. They are a humanitarian org that doesn't care about their employees. The organization is very disjointed as well, one arm doesn't work with the other arm and doesn't know what's happening it.  There are depts working on multiple fronts but not engaging together. There are senior, senior folks that don't work hardly at all/do as they please, don't engage within their teams, don't make needed changes, or make decisions in isolation (without taking feedback of those that know what their stuff). Human resources is overseen by finance - no balance of power. And, the business services/IT department wants to show that they are supporting staff but get in the way instead of being a support service. I've used to hear many frustrations with IT  getting in the way instead of helping.

review_title: Sad Excuse for a Humanitarian Organization
pros: There are not many pros I can identify in regards to leadership. I can state that in spite of all the mismanagement, there are a few employees with pure Humanitarian hearts that still work hard to do what little they can to do good in the world.
cons:
Corruption | Lies | Greed

Starting with the head of the organization and the "Special Consultant" partner going down to the entire Leadership team. The current investigations into theft and corruption are valid. Leadership is more interested in fattening their wallets then they are in sticking to the Organizations Mission.

pros: The people I worked with were great, and that was the hardest part about leaving.  I enjoyed the work I did, and found it to be incredibly challenging and engaging.  I also liked that through the wide variety of programs IMC has you were able to get a lot of different experiences.
cons: There seemed to be a lot of behind the scenes conversations that would go on, and many used knowledge as power.  There was a lot of decisions made, and most of the time employees were notified in a sort of "by the way" manner.

review_title: Needs improvement and change in leadership
pros:
Dedicated and passionate field-based staff
Good benefits, HQ and field based
Competitive salaries for field based staff
cons:
Limited investment in staff growth and retention
Bureaucratic systems which impede quality and timely service delivery to beneficiaries
Finance driven organization focused too much on chasing funding over ensuring quality services
Senior leadership has remained the same for over two decades, no innovation or willingness to make necessary changes to systems at senior levels
Top down management
No strategic vision for the overall organization

review_title: Permanently put me off a career in the charity/NGO sector
Some very great people but the organization doesn't care
pros: I met some of the greatest professional, very prepared and great experienced humanitarian workers. Program quality is good, provided that in this sector there are many challenges and not all projects are implemented well but many imc staff do care and do their best to ensure quality and impact. It's a great organization where to learn and grow professionally for sure. A lot of grants, donors, different contexts, security situations, etc. In just a few years I have improved a lot my skills, competences and passion for this sector.
cons: Senior Management does not care enough about staff wellbeing, they'll keep exploiting workers when teams are understaffed for so long, completely neglecting how staff wellbeing and adequate staffing are key to ensure program quality and in general good work. HR often (not always though) doesn't care much about helping staff or solving their issues, and sometimes they actually make it worse. Most sadly, working at imc you can see many people whose performance is awful and/or are clearly incompetent being promoted and on the other side so many people who are excellent and have done a lot for Imc being neglected and/or ignored. So many people leave because they don't feel recognized or have no opportunities to grow after years at imc. Related to this, there is clearly some corruption or maybe if not corruption misbehavior when hiring people. It's clear some people who have more influence internally "push" for their favorite "friend" candidate to be hired, in some cases I saw interviews being conducted differently to advantage a specific candidate. In other cases you can see just bad attitudes or cultures toward even internal candidates, for example some people trying to influence against someone's recruitment just because of personal reasons and not professional. Internal bureaucracy of the headquarter is really heavy, time wasting and inefficient but senior management are not really listening to everybody else saying there is need to change. After all it doesn't really affect their daily work and promoting change is effort.

pros: Mostly great team to work with in country. Good salary and benefits, excellent RandR policy and accompanying benefits.
cons: Completely dysfunctional management system. Absolutely zero opportunity for staff development. No training or orientation given at all for those who are new to organisation. All decisions must be run through HQ making everything very slow. It appears staff are recruited/promoted/fired based on friendships not professional ability. Would strongly recommend against working for.

review_title: Borken. CEO and Senior Management must be replaced.
pros: Excellent field teams resulting in very good programing, solid and knowledgeable technical and financial systems, flexible and adaptable.  Security department has a good Deputy and knows how to protect staff as best they can.  Nice benefits if abroad.   Anyone below Director level is usually very committed and hardworking.   Media department is solid and professional. Engages in global humanitarian platforms.
cons: Over the past three years IMC has lost 60% of it's excellent  backstopping workforce, all of which  resigned.  The agency has a horrendous CEO and Senior Management Team who do not understand the work the agency does nor gets to learn about the key staff that actually do the job.  Their contact with beneficiaries in almost non existent and their knowledge on humanitarian global affairs is minimal except for one VP.  The agency is run by non- humanitarian business men and an eccentric self obsessed lady,  who emphasize obtaining funding  vs quality programing.  The agency despite having a female CEO has an extremely chauvinistic work environment.   Managers do not build up the workforce and often keep them down; rarely giving subordinates the opportunity to showcase ideas or their work. More often than not, taking credit for the work themselves.  The latter can go on for years without anyone in HR or on the SMT doing anything about it.  There are limited development opportunities for new staff and no opportunities for mid level employees to move up.    Long working hours expected and those who do not work all weekend or late into the night are frowned upon as slackers, and not merely efficient.  The agency has a  very poor ability to raise private funds and the management of this department is heavily criticized by Country teams and most HQ staff  for never coordinating or sharing information.  It has been a long standing joke.  The  Washington DC Office has a particularly sterile and cold working environment and as such  retains little staff these days.  This is a shame because at the beginning most of what is written here was quite the opposite.  However due to changes in staff and the lack of effort on the SMT and HR departments things have deteriorated shamelessly.

review_title: The company has good values and vision, and the projects in eastern Ukraine regions are very useful and really helpful.
pros: Salary is paid twice a month, with no delays. Med insurance for staff exist, but it is very modest.
cons: Staff joins and quits very often. Salaries are lower than market ones, and are revised annually maximum 4%. Mobbing, intriques and schemes do exist. No good coordination of actions or communication between Kyiv and Mariupol. No training or development funds. No open or transparent policies or discussions. People may be fired without

job_title: Field Sites Manager/Head of Field Offices in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
IMC is an International medical NGO with expertise in its areas of intervention. IMC improves the quality of life through health interventions and related activities that build local capacity in underserved communities.

FIrst responder in emergencies.
cons: In general IMC is good organization which is doing a great job on the field to assist people in need. But we have some country directors who are managing a mission like a private property.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Every person working here is positive and passionate about making a positive impact. They will try to take care of your every need. The work done by the field teams is invaluable and saves countless lives.
cons: The various departments and department heads are woefully disconnected, often doubling or throwing away work. Any attempts to seriously improve communication or infrastructure inevitably hits impassable roadblocks. While the work done out in the field is paid utmost attention, internal issues rarely get addressed.

review_title: Toxic organisation, avoid at all costs.
pros: Good salary and benefits, some very good people in the field.
cons:
Very unsupportive environment, toxic work environment where no one makes a decision for fear of being blamed.
HQ has no idea what is needed in the field and does not care. 
Organisation does not care about beneficiaries, not a humanitarian organisation in any way. 
Field staff are overworked and not appreciated.
Zero support for anything from the multiple HQ offices.
Overly bureaucratic with constantly changing policies and procedures.
Routinely hire inept leadership.

pros: Doing diligent and needed health care work overseas!
cons: When I was there, it was a one woman show, how literally controlled everything.   It was like living in a Jail.   However, the intent and delivery of health care services to the needy population,  was noteworthy, and made the work fulfilling.

review_title: Great Office Environment with Best Group of Co-Workers
job_title: Office Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Diverse group of caring, hard working people who believe in a mission that benefits communities in need of help. The people here, of past and present, are amazing to each other and create a great office environment that I feel happy to come into every day.
cons: After 15 years of working here, I don't have any negative comments about this organization.

review_title: Family Physicin and Lecturer in Public Health for 30+
job_title: Family Physician in San Diego, CA
pros: To assists people to promote their health, prevent and control diseases, and rehabilitate them. Treating common conditions, refer to 2ndary or tertiary health care facilities, and then continue followup them.
cons: I don't understand what you mean?

review_title: Avoid organization until long time Senior Management Team is gone!
pros:
Good benefits, flexibility, field visits.
I enjoyed working with the field teams who are dedicated, compassionate and talented. Field staff are committed to humanitarian work who sacrifice a lot to serve their beneficiaries.
cons:
Unfortunately, field teams are left to suffer because of HQ Mgmt. team incompetence and corruption. 
Many talented HQ technical and support staff have left IMC due to mismanagement or fleeing to other humanitarian organizations due to the corruption scandal and USAID suspension.
Mismanagement by executive team starts from the top with the Sr. Leader and Boyfriend who are there to protect own interests and inner circle of managers and other couples.
Poor communications and lack of transparency. 
This is not organization to work for if you value HR support. The new international HR team is poor; under leadership of incompetent leaders run out of LA. I don’t know of a HR or IHR department that could be worse.
Managers prefer to get rid of competent staff to keep friends and family protected. Hiring and promotion based on friendships rather than skill and experience.
Ethics point is a joke. Cases are not investigated properly and HR turns their face on harassment and other issues. Nothing is taken seriously as they are more concerned with protecting the company or leaders.
High Turnover. Lack of care and attention to staff development.
Could have used IMC as a case study in business class of how NOT to run an organization.

review_title: Valuable learning experience in technical field of monitoring and evaluation and humanitarian response
job_title: Monitoring and Evaluation Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: There are many opportunities within the technical unit for professional development and learning about the different sectors, particularly strong in mental health
cons: Due to the nature of humanitarian emergency response, there can be a high level of stress in the office, and among field staff.

pros: If you don't have much experience and can stick it out for a year, it will look good on your resume.  Also, so of the field programs are excellent, but it varies country to country (HQ doesn't set the tone or have quality control internationally) so investigate before you go.
cons:
The management is terrible.  The CEO was related to one of the founders and was given the job in her 20s with no experience.  She has failed to develop leadership or vision and the organization hasn't done anything innovative since the 1980s.  Rather than recruit a group of experienced managers to run the organization, the  Aossey has given the jobs to personal friends, most of whom don't have the training, education or skill sets for the jobs they hold.  As a group, the management is secretive and suspicious.  The HR department exists primarily to undermine employee, and shield ineffective managers from censure and executive decisions from scrutiny.  

Employees are demoralized and the work environment can be tense.  The organization doesn't provide training and has openly adopted the position that it will not invest in employee development.  Basically, the expectation is that, either you will come is as a friend of a senior manager and be given a senior position and a disproportionately high salary, or you will come in, work until you hit a wall and realize that you can't advance, and leave for greener pastures.

review_title: Worst experience in a decade of humanitarian health work
pros: None that I can recollect, except that pay and benefits are decent, probably around the mean for American NGOs
cons:
I think it all comes down to non-existent company values, which trickle down then to general management issues both at HQ and regional levels. As some mentioned above, under-qualified or careless senior management applies a secretive management style based on improvisation as far as operational decision-making is concerned, while personal favoritism concerning HR decisions (in some instances, of the lowest imaginable kind), in total disregard to merit or programmatic needs, allow all sorts of improbable characters to be affected to key regional or country roles, often against the advice of local management. I found it most frustrating when people I line-managed just bypassed to talk to their friends in HQ or the regional office and break all possible management and communication lines. This makes country and program management a nightmare, since no trust is ever possible. I’ve never witnessed this in other American NGOs, where instead often the implicit motto you get is “do or die”. With IMC, you won’t even have the time to show that you can do, since you’ll be basically spied upon from week one.

Internal communication is awful, as is HR management. I was relocated for administrative reasons beyond my or IMC’s control out of my base country to a third country (not my own country), but once it became clear it was not possible for me to resume work where I was originally posted, they rescinded my contract with a week’s notice (under Christmas!) and even said I should pay my return fees myself to come and recollect my items! Ironically, just 6 months after a formal complaint and strong wording against the management, HR contacted me for another senior position, like no actualized HR records existed. Unfortunately, this means also that awful workers fired somewhere just turn up into the agencies sometimes in the future.

Personal rants aside, what is worst is that for an agency having a highly technical mandate, these “senior managers” parachuted from above by friendly supervisors at HQ come with limited technical background (especially in public health), arrogance and lack of diplomacy, severely affecting relations with both donors and country officials. One regional manager boasted once about having received several death threats in several countries, and she seemed to think it was actually a good thing and something to be proud of.

In short, if you’re experienced, look for transparent management structures, a positive organizational culture, a like to work in public health in complex post-emergency or transitional contexts, don’t go there. If you’re just starting up, or you’re an emergency cowboy/girl who cares little of HR support should something smelly hit the fan, or you just like health work so much that you couldn’t care less of who manages you, and just think about doing your job, it can be a decently-paid option for a short/medium term.

pros: You can meet some nice people, but not at the higher levels. Good overall mission.
cons: Extremely demanding and unhealthy work environment, feedback is either negative or neutral. Senior Management is only concerned about bringing in money. Lack of interest in professional growth or development of employees. No one is happy. Salary below market, unless you are a senior staff member. Complaints to HR never taken seriously, they are more concerned with protecting the company than the individual. Would never recommend. Do not work here.

review_title: Avoid if you're looking for a long term role with a quality agency
pros: The national staff are motivated, enthusiastic and believe in the mission.  The services delivered are needed and in much needed locations.  Pay and benefits are fair.
cons:
Most of these reviews have already articulated the experience of working at IMC better than I can - it's not a wholly positive experience.  Overall, I think the agency is operating in away that is unethical and possibly harmful to those it's seeking to assist.  Donors would be better off investing elsewhere.

The organization is micromanaged by it's HQ, in such as way as to render it ineffective.  The systems are designed to presumably improve transparency, but realistically any of the paperwork can be manipulated by people who know the system.  What is missing is a focus on needs and the programs themselves - shouldn't this factor into decision-making?

The turnover of HQ and international staff is pretty incredible, the organization is hemorrhaging people.  I hesitate to say 'good people' however - staff seem to be promoted or deployed based on friendships and time spent with the organization, not actual skill and experience.  This is a vicious cycle - poor promoting leads to more poor decision-making and more poor choices.  This is not a place to go if you want to grow and learn in your job.

This is the first NGO I have worked were I've seriously had to consider fraud and ethics in the workplace; some of the decision-making and behaviors I have witnessed are truly unacceptable.  Sometimes it is hard to tell if the lack of normal systems and experienced staff means bad decision-making is the result of genuine naivety or intentional disregard.

IMC is focused on money, not people or quality.  Communications from senior management are non-existent, there are a high percentage of staff wondering if they have a job each morning.  Benefits for international staff were recently reduced, with no clear explanation or prior warning.  You actually need to attend a training session to be able to understand your payslip.  This is not the place to come if you value HR support.

pros: Starting out as an intern, there was so much room to grow, sad the program had to come to a close.  Employees welfare is highly valued.
cons: Give interns some sort of medical cover, the stipend is on the lowest side .

review_title: Worked as an advisor at the UK office
pros: IMC have some brilliant staff and are doing some great work in the field. The salaries are good and senior management are accessible.
cons: As with most INGOs they have a few organisational issues but not enough to put off a potential candidate.

pros: Reaches a lot of people and the field teams are incredible. If you can make it long enough to make friends, people are very loyal. There is some great work being done, but this organization will lose everyone because they are so resistant to change. Pay rate is within cost of living for DC, but not high enough to be subject to abuse and on-call all the time. Fantastic healthcare if you are single.
cons: If you refuse to submit to abusive management, then they will do everything in their power to get rid of you. They want robots who don't ask questions. If they like you, there may be room for advancement, if not, then you'll be gone - however in most departments there really is zero room for advancement. No use of strengths-based management styles. Unless you are a senior level officer, you are basically a secretary and will be treated as such. Many people in HQ offices are on-call all the time and have to take calls at ridiculous hours - absolutely zero respect for work-life balance and boundaries. Extremely high turn-over rates - most people seem to leave after a year. Many people in management who have zero skills and should not be managers, but they've simply been there the longest or are friends with the senior staff. Too much white saviorism from rich white people. Most of senior management is white - they use the overseas field staff to pad their diversity stats. Don't expect to afford to add healthcare benefits for your spouse or kids unless you are at least senior level - costs either $1400/month or $700 for the low plan with the $12K family deductible. Top-down approach to humanitarianism, which goes against current research.

pros: It's amazing working for a company that you know is doing amazing work abroad in over 30 countries.
cons: If only  they treated their employees in Los Angeles as well as the people they're helping abroad. Upper management has no idea what hell middle management forces upon people below them. Not enough workers, too much work to be done and not communicated clearly.

pros: I have experience with IMC for one year and half in Syria branch and now i am in Germany. I am interessting with IMC tasks and goals and i want to be a part from IMC again.
cons: I don't have any idea about the atmosphere in Germany and how works goes on.

pros: Field staff is hardworking and trying to make a difference in communities.
cons: HQ top managment needs to be replaced asap, as most of them don't know what are they doing and never visit field to understand programs. Horrible atmosphere, no communication, no transparency! Departments not communicating properly with each other, which results in lots of mistakes, unnecessary workloads and frustration among staff. Entire organization is HQ and finance oriented instead of focusing on field teams and programs!

review_title: IMC does good work in the world, but it depends on your manager/supervisor if you get any recognition as an individual.
pros: They do good work in the world, and you can feel good about that.
cons: You may not get the support from your supervisor. Kind of a "sink or swim" atmosphere

job_title: Case Manager in South Lebanon, OH
pros: provide health and mental health services all over lebanon without discrimination. it takes into consideration the needs of  lebanese and other nationalities people.
cons: non sustainibility and strategic plans so centers open and close without making exit strategy which is very frustrating for beneficiaries.

review_title: good experience allow me to corporate with different kind of people
pros:
global, humanitarian, nonprofit organization dedicated to saving lives and relieving suffering through health care training and relief and development programs.
 it gives you good experience
cons: working in this organization feels good but there is big issue that employees stick to a position and its hard to get promotion for better position

review_title: Long working hours, no support from HQ Split Office
job_title: Finance Director in Juba, South Darfur
pros: Good salary  , thats all thats there
cons:
No salary scale
Split office is pushy and giving no support at all, too much internal control departments that are overlaping each other
Overtime no compensated
Programme team is constantly shifting, huge staff turnover in UK office

pros:
the best reasons to work at IMC because they treat employees like family and respect them 
i think IMC is the best ngo in baghdad
cons: the most faimous downside at IMC are they dont have a development or training projects for thier employees for management and adminstration

review_title: It's more important who you know than what you know.
pros: The organization has a great mission and lots of room to improve. Joining IMC you feel there is so much opportunity to play a part in making it a better organization.
cons: People get burned out and leave without making a dent in those opportunities. Those who advance are close to the C-Suite and those who stand on the shoulders of their colleagues claiming the work of others as their own. It's toxic.

review_title: I was a mastermind to lead ,planning and managing  HIV/AIDS Program of Ethiopia USAID Livestock Project at IMC
job_title: Senior HIV/AIDS Advisor in Addis Ababa
pros: There are plenty of reasons that makes working for IMC is an enjoyable and interesting among them are: work freedom , strong team works and talented technical expertise
cons: Not much  challenges were observed

pros: As many of the reviews say, the field teams, programs-support staff, keep the organization moving and do incredible work. They work hard--and are still walked all over.
cons: Again--as many reviews say and will say time and time and time again until something changes, the CEO and her BF have to go. Change now needs to come from the top down, to whomever is left standing.

review_title: Believed in work being done in the field, but HQ leadership difficult to work for.
pros: Great cause.  Great volunteers and field staff.  Important work.
cons: Leadership at HQ is volatile, secretive and power hungry.

pros: Great mission, very nice people
cons: Management lacks the necessary skills to move forward in becoming a larger company.  All decisions (all!!) are routed through a single individual in LA.  As you can imagine it is a very slow and cumbersome process.

pros: Great exposure, qualified people, good work
cons: HQs, most of the staff at HQs are not qualified. No real leader at the moment to direct this organization and find a goal or work toward it. It's a mess however i still would consider working again there.

pros: One of the BEST in the field , committed to deliver on time to people in need . Excellent in emergency response . IMC have one the best LOGISTICS and FINANCE team for emergency response.
cons: Need to increase support to field team in making right and quick decisions on the field.

pros: Can-do emergency response organization that hits the ground running - stick to it!
cons: Senior leadership lost only VP that went to the field last year - who is listening?

pros: Good system of benefits, salary, team is good
cons: Aggressive CD Colantoni, yells at people, inconsistent, keeps telling people he’s untouchable, uses bad words all the time. Lies a lot. Hates people around him.

pros: My supervisor is one of the best people and manager you can work with. But I think this is my chance. Cause most of the employees have some problems with SMT in general.
cons: I don't know if an HR department could be worse?

pros: Does some great work in the field
cons: Not a good place for staff, HQ seems to be completely clueless, processes done by rote with no rhyme or reason, technical advisors at HQ are not particularly helpfuk

review_title: To facilitate the empowerment of individuals to overcome  turmoil in their environment regardless of the cause.
pros: Bringing self-sufficiency and assurance in the lives of individuals who were hopeless and helpless due to situational disaster.
cons: To remain creative with a sense of leadership at all times.

pros: Good Salary compared to other NGO's.  They go to areas where many NGO's refuse to go. They have a great logistic team.
cons: I do not think there are any Cons, they are a great NGO to work for and go the extra step to accomplish goals.

review_title: Great workplace and colleagues and fulfilling work
pros: The mission to help those in need, encouragement from leadership to always learn and improve, wonderful coworkers
cons: HR policy is confusing at times but they seem to be working to improve things

job_title: Senior Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Interesting and valuable work in incredible areas of the world serving those most in need.
cons: Leadership out of touch, poor HR, fear to make decisions, no central clear lines of authority because departments are not consolidated

review_title: Overall a good organisation but HR is not consistent
pros: Lots of freedom to work in the technical sector and ability to create your own work in additional to the day to day work
cons: HR policy is in place but the execution is different for each person.

pros: I've worked for other NGOs before and IMC is certainly working with very professional and competent employees; it usually takes more experience to become part of their team than with other NGOs.
cons: I can't think of any cons at the moment.

pros: Very good environment, committed people, high qualified professionals, very good impact with the beneficiaries, well known by donors.
cons: High turnover, weak planning, no visibility for the future, weak leadership, no clear management direction.

pros: Great staff in the field; exceptional emergency response capacity
cons: Becoming increasingly risk adverse and losing sight of the humanitarian imperative

pros: through this i believe i could earn me learning more and get more knowledge with international figures
cons: i pretty sure there would be any disadvantages  specially for a more bright minded person like me

review_title: One of the top non-profit in the sector
pros: Friendly working environment. Structures and easy access to top management. Balanced between professional and personal life.
cons: Low salaries and benefits. Mostly contractual jobs.

review_title: Needs a change in senior management. CEO and VPs need to go.
pros: Some committed field teams, with understanding of humanitarian principles. Battling against organizational systems that cannot be implemented, I feel for them and the beneficiaries.
cons: VPs and CEO only interested in lining their own pockets, would rather see programs fail and close than consider their own positions.

pros: Salary and the benefits are good
cons: Only short contracts are offered

pros:
- varied tasks
- able to get involved with numerous projects
cons:
- micro-mangement
- not great compensation

pros:
- Nice work environment
- Direct Contact with beneficiaries
- Helping people in need, and work in places where no other international org. will go
cons:
